items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck due to heavy rainfall forecast this afternoon into this evening. Areas most at risk include low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Flooding is possible on low-lying land and roads from early evening today into the early hours of tomorrow 10/10/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Highest tide level is expected to be at Kilnsea Village between 6 AM until 8:30 AM and 6pm until 9:30pm on 10/10/2022, then . We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated following the tide tomorrow morning, 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.79mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.24m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.55mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.41m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12pm and 2pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.55mAODN at 1pm, Monday 10th October, which is 0.41m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 4pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 06:30am and 08:30am tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.61mAODN at 07:30am, Monday 10th October, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 12:15pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 06:30am and 08:30am tomorrow, Monday 10th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.61mAODN at 07:30am, Monday 10th October, which is 0.34m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 12:15pm tomorrow, Monday 10th October.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to heavy rainfall forecast this afternoon into this evening. Areas most at risk include low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
Flooding is possible on low-lying land and roads from early evening today into the early hours of tomorrow 10/10/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk due to heavy rainfall forecast this afternoon into this evening.  Areas most at risk include low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk and other watercourses, from Harrington to Annaside including low lying areas around Whitehaven, Cleator Moor, Egremont, Gosforth, Eskdale and Bootle.  Flooding is possible on low-lying land and roads from early evening today into the early hours of tomorrow 10/10/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to heavy rainfall forecast this afternoon into this evening.  Areas most at risk include low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot. Flooding is possible on low-lying land and roads from early evening today into the early hours of tomorrow 10/10/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels have receded but lake levels remain high following a response to recent heavy rain.  Further heavy rain forecast this afternoon into this evening will increase levels once again on rivers and the lakes for a time.  Derwent Water remains high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water.  Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides, tides will be at their highest this evening at 06:30 PM on 09/10/2022.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible between 5:30 PM and 8:30 PM on 09/10/2022.
The forecast is dry for this afternoon with a light to moderate southerly wind.
The tide on Monday evening is expected to be high due to the spring tides and may result in us issuing a further alert.
Our incident response staff are checking defences and will be onsite during the high water levels should any defences need to be operated.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads due to the high water level.
We will remove this message by 10:00 PM on 09/10/2022.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:45 PM on 09/10/2022.
Flooding is possible at the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale between 9:45 PM on 09/10/2022 and 01:45 AM on 10/10/2022.
The lunchtime high tide tomorrow on 10/10/2022 will not meet any Flood Alert thresholds however, the tide at 00:30 AM on 11/10/22 will exceed the Flood Alert threshold and will be issued ahead of this tide.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated ahead of the high tide tomorrow evening on 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Caldew and Petteril
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Rivers Caldew and Petteril due to heavy rainfall forecast this afternoon into this evening.  Areas most at risk include low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to Carlisle including Greystoke, Newton Reigny, Plumpton, Stockdalewath, Sebergham and Denton Holme in Carlisle. 
Flooding is possible on low-lying land and roads from early evening today into the early hours of tomorrow 10/10/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message: River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of a high tide tomorrow morning, 10/10/2022. Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland, is expected between 00:30 and 01:30 am on 10/10/2022 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 00:30, and 01:15 am, Eastford Road, between 00:45, and 01:30 am, and Arpley Bridge, between 00:45, and 01:30 am. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. After this high tide no further impacts are currently expected. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00 am tomorrow 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
High tides and a tidal surge have combined to make water levels higher than usual as a result of spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 06:30 and 08:30 tomorrow, 10/10/22. Flooding to the promenade for Hunstanton seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Coastal conditions should ease for the 10/10/22 high tide at 19:30.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with King’s Lynn and West Norfolk Borough Council. The Local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.16mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.20m. The forecast tide level is 4.66mAOD. The forecast wind direction is north-westerly. The forecast wind strength is 5.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 10/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
High tides and a tidal surge have combined to make water levels higher than usual as a result of spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 6:30 and 8:30 tomorrow, 10/10/22. Flooding is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. Coastal conditions should ease for the 10/10/22 high tide at 19:30. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.16mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.20m. The forecast tide level is 4.66mAOD. The forecast wind direction is north-westerly. The forecast wind strength is 5.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 10/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides , tides will be at their highest this evening at 11:45 PM on 09/10/2022.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 11:45 PM on 09/10/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides , tides will be at their highest this evening at 11:45 PM on 09/10/2022.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss at 11:45 PM on 09/10/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the evening, but will clear.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Lune and Conder
items.message:
River levels will rise steadily on the River Lune; River Conder and Burrow Beck due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster.
Flooding is possible at River Lune, Conder, Keer, Burrow Beck and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster from 11:00 PM on 09/10/2022.
River levels are expected to remain high overnight.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Highest tide level is expected to be at North Quay Road, Whitby between 04:30 AM and 05:00 AM on 10/10/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated following the tide tomorrow morning, 10/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message: River levels have receded but lake levels remain high following a response to recent heavy rain. Derwent Water remains high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.  Further heavy rain forecast this afternoon into this evening will increase levels once again on rivers and the lakes for a time. Rivers will peak later this evening and Derwent Water peaking at 05:00 hrs tomorrow morning, 10/10/22. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 10/10/2022 or as the situation changes.
